Directed Acyclic Graphs

Author

Arpit Kumar Pandey

Parking Spot - DAG

library(tidyverse)
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)

dag <- 'dag {
bb="0,0,1,1"
Parking [exposure,pos="0.1,0.5"]
Sales [outcome,pos="0.5,0.5"]
Location [pos="0.3,1"]
Parking -> Sales
Location -> Parking
Location -> Sales
}
'
ggdag_status(dag) + theme_dag()

Data analysis

Loading the data frame

df <- readRDS("Causal_Data_Science_Data/customer_sat.rds")

head(df)
# Show table
df
# Get glimpse of data
glimpse(df)
#> Rows: 15
#> Columns: 3
#> $ follow_ups   <dbl> 8, 7, 8, 9, 10, 6, 7, 6, 8, 8, 0, 1, 2, 2, 3
#> $ satisfaction <dbl> 40, 45, 47, 44, 50, 55, 60, 62, 59, 65, 70, 74, 77, 74, 80
#> $ subscription <chr> "Elite", "Elite", "Elite", "Elite", "Elite", "Premium+", …
summary(df, digits = 3)
#>    follow_ups     satisfaction  subscription      
#>  Min.   : 0.00   Min.   :40.0   Length:15         
#>  1st Qu.: 2.50   1st Qu.:48.5   Class :character  
#>  Median : 7.00   Median :60.0   Mode  :character  
#>  Mean   : 5.67   Mean   :60.1                     
#>  3rd Qu.: 8.00   3rd Qu.:72.0                     
#>  Max.   :10.00   Max.   :80.0
# Select only numeric columns
df_numeric <- df[sapply(df, is.numeric)]

# Calculate correlation matrix
cor(df_numeric)
#>              follow_ups satisfaction
#> follow_ups    1.0000000   -0.8111461
#> satisfaction -0.8111461    1.0000000

1. Regress satisfaction on follow_ups

lm_model <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df)

summary(lm_model)
#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -12.412  -5.257   1.733   4.506  12.588 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  78.8860     4.2717  18.467 1.04e-10 ***
#> follow_ups   -3.3093     0.6618  -5.001 0.000243 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.658,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.6316 
#> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF,  p-value: 0.0002427

2. Regress satisfaction on follow_ups and account for subscription

lm_model_subscription <- lm(satisfaction ~ ., data = df)

summary(lm_model_subscription)
#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ ., data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -4.3222 -2.1972  0.3167  2.2667  3.9944 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)           26.7667     6.6804   4.007  0.00206 ** 
#> follow_ups             2.1944     0.7795   2.815  0.01682 *  
#> subscriptionPremium   44.7222     5.6213   7.956 6.88e-06 ***
#> subscriptionPremium+  18.0722     2.1659   8.344 4.37e-06 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9597, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9487 
#> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF,  p-value: 5.956e-08

Compare the coefficients and find a possible explanation.

  • In the model without a subscription, the coefficient is -3.3093, indicating that without a subscription, follow-ups decrease customer satisfaction. Conversely, in the model with a subscription, the coefficient is 2.1944, suggesting that with a subscription, follow-ups increase customer satisfaction. The coefficients for Premium and Premium+ are +44.7222 and +18.0722, respectively, signifying that being on these subscription levels is associated with substantial increases in satisfaction compared to the base category. I believe customers find it intrusive when they are followed up without any subscription, potentially due to having fewer features. On the other hand, premium and elite customers seem to perceive the follow-ups more positively. This impact is also reflected in the variance R2 and R2 (Adjusted), where both values increased, indicating that the model now better explains the variance in satisfaction, highlighting the significance of subscription level in understanding customer satisfaction.

Plot the data

Without Conditioning on Subscription

simps_not_cond  <- ggplot(df, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction)) +
  geom_point(alpha = .8) +
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = F)

simps_not_cond
#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

Conditioning on Subscription

simps_cond <- ggplot(df, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction, color = subscription )) +
  geom_point(alpha = .8) +
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = F) +
  theme(legend.position = "right")

simps_cond 
#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
